summary.en: Right to Quality Health Care. All medical staff should communicate with you throughout your visit. If you are unsure of anything that is happening, you have the right to ask them to stop and expliain what is happening. You also have a right to decline care or to ask for more information before consenting to any procedure or intervention. A Well Women'c Check is performed by your GP or OB/GYN, and consists of the following:

text.en: A well women’s test is done by your GP or Ob/gyn, and consists of a medical interview, a physical exam, a pap test, and a breast exam.

This is a screening to test cervical cells for irregularities that could potentially lead to cervical cancer. The cervix is a narrow passage at the bottom of the uterus. Up to 90% of cervical cancers can be prevented by having a regular pap test. This test is to be done every two years  but will soon be moved to every five years for all women starting one to two years after becoming sexually active for the first time until 70 years of age.

A breast exam is done by a medical practitioner during a well women’s check by massaging the breast and under the armpits in a number of different ways in order to feel for lumps or changes in the tissue. If something abnormal is felt then you will be referred to have a mammogram (breast x-ray) and possibly to have a biopsy of the tissue in order to make sure the lump is not cancerous. Talk to your GP about the best way to self-check for breast changes in the privacy of your own home.

title.en: The Five Steps of a Breast Self-Exam

text.en: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)- A UTI is any infection to the urethra, bladder, ureters, or kidneys. It can cause symptoms that include: burning with urination, increased urinary frequency, urinating only small amounts, odorous urine, and lower back pain. UTIs are diagnosed with a urine sample and treated with antibiotics./n/n Thrush-  Vaginal thrush is an infection that most women get at some point in their life. It can feel like an itching and/or burning sensation and can leave your vaginal and vulval area looking red and cause a white discharge. It is mostly harmless and is caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans yeast. You should visit your chemist for a vaginal cream or tablets (both oral and vaginal are available), but should see your doctor if it occurs more than twice during a single year. Thrush can also occur in other parts of the body, such as the mouth and is often the result of antibiotic use as these alter the balance of good and bad bacteria in the body./n/nPolycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a hormonal syndrome linked to high levels of androgen hormones in the body. These hormones can lead to fluctuations in the menstrual cycle, weight gain, fertility issues, and psychological effects./n/n Incontinence- Incontinence is the uncontrolled leakage of urine or feces. Causes for this vary, but one common cause of urinary incontinence can be childbirth.

Menopause: Menopause is when a woman stops her menstrual cycle and ovulating (release eggs), and typically occurs around 50 years of age. Menopause is said to have occurred when she has stopped menstruating for more than a year. When this occurs the hormones that control menstruation lower and can cause a multitude of side effects including: hot flashes, vaginal changes, and mood fluctuations. /n/n Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a hormonal syndrome linked to high levels of androgen hormones in the body. These hormones can lead to fluctuations in the menstrual cycle, weight gain, fertility issues, and psychological effects. /n/n Prolapse- A prolapse can occur when muscles in your pelvic floor are weakened and the muscle and tendons that hold pelvic organs in place stretch or tear causing vaginal (or other pelvic organs) to descend through the vagina.
